item.title: Drug Charges for Nephews of Venezuela’s First Lady Could Add to Public Distrust
item.description: Though President Nicolás Maduro’s wife, Cilia Flores, has been accused of nepotism in the past, the recent family scandal could be especially problematic as legislative elections approach.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

item.title: Aeroflot Heeds the Call to Buy Russian
item.description: As Russia struggles under sanctions and low oil prices, it is calling on its national champions for help.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Sukhoi Superjet at Sheremetyevo, an international airport northwest of Moscow.

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Deadly Blasts in Southern Beirut
item.description: The bombings, near a Palestinian refugee camp that has absorbed many Syrians, killed at least 43 people, according to the Lebanese Health Ministry.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: In recent years, Beirut has been subjected to bombings and other attacks carried out in the name of rival factions in the Syrian civil war.

item.title: André Glucksmann, French Philosopher Who Renounced Marxism, Dies at 78
item.description: After publishing his most influential work, “The Master Thinkers,” Mr. Glucksmann became one of France’s most prominent public intellectuals.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: André Glucksmann, left, with Jean-Paul Sartre in Paris. Mr. Glucksmann came to prominence in May 1968, when, as a teacher at the Sorbonne, he publicly cheered on the student revolt there.

item.title: Kurdish Forces Retake Strategic Highway in Iraq’s North From ISIS
item.description: They gained control over a major jihadist supply line as part of a broader offensive to reclaim the town of Sinjar. The Times has two reporters on the front lines.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga fighters warmed themselves by a fire at their position east of Sinjar on Thursday evening after their unit cut off Highway 47, a main road between Mosul and Raqqa, earlier in the day.

item.title: Regional Newspapers Weigh In on Syria Talks
item.description: Editorial opinion in the region is divided over whether international talks this weekend in Vienna have any chance of reaching a postwar political deal to end the civil war in Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Artur Mas Loses Bid to Remain Leader in Catalonia
item.description: The vote by Catalan lawmakers throws into chaos the region’s three-year drive for independence from Spain.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Uzbekistan Releases Political Prisoner After 21 Years
item.description: The prisoner, Murod Juraev, had been imprisoned since Sept. 18, 1994, and was sometimes called the world’s longest-serving political prisoner by rights groups.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ezra F. Vogel on China’s Shifting Relations With Japan and Taiwan
item.description: Dispirited by mounting tensions between the two countries, Mr. Vogel, a Harvard sociologist, has set out to promote a deeper understanding of their relationship across time.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: News Analysis: Myanmar Generals Set the Stage for Their Own Exit
item.description: The military let the vote take place unimpeded, and while that posture could change, all signs point to a peaceful transfer of power to the National League for Democracy.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I would have regretted it for the rest of my life if I didn’t vote for Daw Suu,” said Daw Myint Myint Than, a civil servant, explaining her support for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her National League for Democracy.

item.title: Russia Says Leak of Secret Nuclear Weapon Design Was an Accident
item.description: Portrayed as an accidental disclosure, the Russian news media’s reporting of a nuclear-armed drone submarine appeared to be a deliberate tactic by the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Any Paris Climate Deal Must Be Legally Binding, French Leader Says
item.description: President François Hollande was responding to remarks by Secretary of State John Kerry, who said that any agreement reached at the climate conference was “not going to be a treaty.”
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: U.N. Security Council Seeks to Head Off Mass Atrocities in Burundi
item.description: The Security Council called for a bolstered international presence in the East African nation but stopped short of sanctions against those who incite violence.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Europe Nears Accord With Turkey to Stem Tide of Refugees
item.description: Europe offered Turkey $3.2 billion dollars to cope with two million Syrian refugees there so they stay out and invited Turkey to discussions that could aid its efforts to join the European Union.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: From left, Prime Minister Juha Sipila of Finland, Prime Minister Xavier Bettel of Luxembourg, and Prime Minister Stefan Lofven of Sweden at the Valletta summit meeting on migration in Malta on Thursday.

item.title: Palestinian Dies as Undercover Israelis Raid a Hospital
item.description: Video emerged showing Israeli forces disguised in traditional Arab outfits as they burst in to make an arrest. One man was killed.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Mourners at the funeral of a man killed by Israeli undercover forces in a raid at Al-Ahli hospital, in the West Bank.

item.title: On the Road in Syria, Struggle All Around
item.description: The police are gone, and militias have flourished, snarling traffic with checkpoints. And abandoned government offices house ad hoc administrations that struggle to keep the lights on.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters killed in 2014 in Kobani were buried last month in Qamishli. Recovery of the bodies had been impossible before.

item.title: Vatican Investigates 2 Journalists Over Leaked Documents
item.description: The journalists, Gianluigi Nuzzi and Emiliano Fittipaldi, used the documents for two books that detailed alleged incompetence and greed within the Vatican’s administrative body.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: A Refugee Crisis in Lebanon Hides in Plain Sight
item.description: Over one million Syrians have sought refuge in a country of barely four million people, and the strains have passed what anyone envisioned was the breaking point.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohammad Jassem, 12, trying to sell roses in Beirut's Hamra district. One of more than a million Syrian refugees in Lebanon, he has not been to school for the past three years, instead selling roses to help support his family.

item.title: Pomp, Protests Greet India's Premier Modi on Lavish UK Visit
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and British counterpart David Cameron vowed Thursday to use U.K. knowhow and investment to help modernize the world's largest democracy, as Modi was greeted with official honors and noisy protests in London.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 2 Said to Be Venezuelan First Lady’s Nephews Charged in Drug Plot
item.description: The two men were identified in an indictment unsealed in Manhattan as Efraín Antonio Campo Flores and Franqui Francisco Flores de Freitas, said to be nephews of Cilia Flores.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and WILLIAM NEUMAN
